importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Andrew sent an email to Jeffrey Epstein on this date stating they were 'in this together', which contradicted previous claims and fueled allegations of continued ties to Epstein.
Andrew gave up all public duties and charity roles in November 2019 following a damaging interview about his relationship with Epstein and the Giuffre allegations.
The latest probe by London police into Prince Andrew's conduct occurred on this date, marking a renewed public scrutiny of his actions and associations.
Virginia Giuffre died by suicide in April 2025, adding emotional weight and moral urgency to the ongoing investigation and public debate about accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The key events — including Andrew’s contact with Epstein, the request to investigate Giuffre’s background, and the subsequent public revelations — span from 2011 to 2025, illustrating a prolonged pattern of controversy and royal scandal.
Since 2019, the monarchy has taken measures to distance itself from Prince Andrew, culminating in his title relinquishment and ongoing public scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Prince Andrew is under investigation by London police for allegedly instructing a bodyguard to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record in 2011, raising concerns about potential smear tactics.
The investigation arises from media reports that Andrew provided his bodyguard with Giuffre’s date of birth and social security number to check her background.
Giuffre, who was trafficked by Epstein in 2001 and died by suicide in April 2025, is central to the allegations, with her family calling for the stripping of Andrew’s title by King Charles III.
Andrew previously denied all allegations in a 2022 out-of-court settlement, where he acknowledged Giuffre’s suffering but denied wrongdoing.
The controversy intensified after a BBC interview in which Andrew claimed to have cut off contact with Epstein in 2010, but emails revealed he continued communication with Epstein in 2011.
British Energy Secretary Ed Miliband condemned the idea of using a police officer to conduct a smear campaign, emphasizing that such actions are inappropriate and unethical.
The public and political pressure on the royal family has grown significantly, especially after years of tawdry headlines and revelations about Andrew’s connections with Epstein and Giuffre.

summaryOfNewsArticle: London police are investigating whether Prince Andrew, in 2011, instructed his bodyguard to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record, raising allegations of a smear campaign. Giuffre, who claims she was trafficked by Epstein and had a sexual relationship with Andrew, died by suicide in April 2025. Andrew previously denied all claims, including in a 2022 out-of-court settlement where he acknowledged her suffering. The controversy was intensified by emails showing Andrew remained in contact with Epstein in 2011, contradicting past denials. The investigation follows years of public criticism and growing pressure on the royal family, including calls from Giuffre’s family for King Charles III to strip Andrew of his title. British Energy Secretary Ed Miliband condemned the use of a police officer in such a campaign, calling it unethical.
title: Police Looking Into Whether Prince Andrew Enlisted Officer to Dig Up Dirt on Accuser Giuffre
